Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: FEM-based inverse methods to estimate nonlinear geometric source parameters of volcano deformation from geodetic data
Award.AbstractNarration:
The migration of magma within a volcano produces a deformation signature at the Earth's surface. The location, shape, and pressurization of the magma chamber, as well as the internal structure of the rocks surrounding the magma chamber, control the specific deformation pattern that can be observed at the surface of the volcano. Quantifying the characteristics of magma migration is important, because the upward migration of magma is a precursor to volcanic eruptions. This project will develop finite element models (FEMs), a type of numerical method, to simulate volcanoes as a dynamic system that accounts for the interaction of migrating magma within the complex internal structure of an active volcano. These FEMs will be used in inverse methods that seek to quantify estimates and uncertainties of a few characteristic parameters that describe magma migration into, or out of, a magma chamber. These methods will be developed in the context of two volcanoes (Okmok, Alaska, and Tungurahua, Ecuador) that will serve as natural laboratories. Both of these active volcanoes have known internal structures in the form of tomography models estimated using data from ground-based seismic instruments, as well as surface deformation histories that were recorded with geodetic data (e.g., GPS data and satellite radar imagery) over the past decade. More specifically, this project will use FEM-based inverse analyses of geodetic data to determine estimates and uncertainties for the location, shape, and pressurization of magma chambers embedded in the complex internal structures of these two active volcanoes. More generally, this project will develop methods to integrate volcano geodesy and seismology, two traditionally disparate geophysical fields of study. This integration is poised to advance the fundamental understanding of active volcanoes.

This project comprises collaborative research among early-career and mid-career faculty and graduate education at the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSMT), an EPSCoR institution. SDSMT is a regional center for science and engineering research and is ideally located to interface with a substantial local Native American community. The proposed methods will provide powerful numerical techniques to combine different types of information that are customarily used independently from one another to assess volcano hazards. This ability to simultaneously analyze different types of information will provide a more complete picture of the internal processes for a given active volcano and will likely lead to more reliable predictions of volcanic behavior. The methods developed by this project will be designed to be generally amenable for other analyses of volcano deformation and ultimately provide important societal benefits of more reliable natural hazards assessments. Another impact of this project is its direct relevance to studies of earthquake deformation, which are driven by analogous configurations of deformation sources embedded in complex structures associated with active faults. Thus, the techniques developed for this project may be readily extended to studies of earthquake deformation and may have important implications for future analyses of seismic and tsunami hazards worldwide.

Institution.Name: South Dakota School of Mines and Technology
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: SOUTH DAKOTA SCHOOL OF MINES & TECHNOLOGY

Performance_Institution.Name: South Dakota School of Mines and Technology

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The upward migration of magma controls the eruption cycle of an active volcano. The specific location, shape, and pressurization of the chamber that receives the magma, along with and surrounding rocks that host the magma chamber within an active volcano, produce a specific deformation signature at the Earth’s surface. This project addressed the challenging problem of characterizing the magma migration and storage, based on observed deformation of the Earth’s surface. Okmok volcano, Alaska, was the chosen target of this analysis, because Okmok is one of the best instrumented and highly studied volcanoes in the world. The deformation of Okmok is characterized by satellite radar data. Seismic data are used to image Okmok’s interior, but this imaging contains uncertainties and is thus not perfect. This project developed sophisticated models that could ingest both satellite radar and seismic imaging information to estimate the location, shape, and pressurization of a magma chamber. Results identified sensitivities to how individual types of information contributed to the estimates when used independently or collectively. Results from models based on surface deformation from satellite radar data alone indicated that the magma chamber depth is 3100 meters below the surface of the volcano. However, a model that simulates a magma chamber embedded in a more complicated distribution of materials, as indicated by seismic imaging, indicates a significantly deeper magma chamber having a depth of 3900 meters below the volcano’s surface. This result suggests that ignoring the seismic imaging information will strongly influence depth estimates of the volcano’s magmatic system. These results were found to be insensitive to the uncertainties in the seismic imaging. This implies that seismic imaging information, even if poorly focused, is essential to estimating the characteristics of a magma system, based on surface deformation data. These results are important for Okmok, as well as other volcanoes world-wide, because an accurate understanding of a magmatic system is essential for volcano eruption hazard assessments.

 

The past few decades produced an explosion of data streams for active volcanoes, thanks to recent advances in space-borne instrumentation and computational capabilities. The project supported and served as the basis for Dr. Theodore Donovan’s Ph.D. research, which addressed the critical need for methods capable of integrating multiple types of information to advance our understanding of active volcanic systems. PI Masterlark and Dr. Donovan devised and executed sophisticated numerical models using the High Performance Computing hardware acquired by this project as a means achieve the project objectives. While the methods were specifically designed for Okmok Volcano, they are readily transportable for use to study other volcanoes having multiple types of information. Both PI Masterlark and Dr. Donovan presented preliminary results at multiple conferences during the project period in an effort to (1) inform  the scientific community of their progress, (2) obtain insightful feedback from other researchers, and (3) ensure the free exchange of ideas regarding the project. Results were published and documented in peer-reviewed scientific journals and are thus available to the public.

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2017
Modified by: Timothy L Masterlark

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The upward migration of magma controls the eruption cycle of an active volcano. The specific location, shape, and pressurization of the chamber that receives the magma, along with and surrounding rocks that host the magma chamber within an active volcano, produce a specific deformation signature at the Earth?s surface. This project addressed the challenging problem of characterizing the magma migration and storage, based on observed deformation of the Earth?s surface. Okmok volcano, Alaska, was the chosen target of this analysis, because Okmok is one of the best instrumented and highly studied volcanoes in the world. The deformation of Okmok is characterized by satellite radar data. Seismic data are used to image Okmok?s interior, but this imaging contains uncertainties and is thus not perfect. This project developed sophisticated models that could ingest both satellite radar and seismic imaging information to estimate the location, shape, and pressurization of a magma chamber. Results identified sensitivities to how individual types of information contributed to the estimates when used independently or collectively. Results from models based on surface deformation from satellite radar data alone indicated that the magma chamber depth is 3100 meters below the surface of the volcano. However, a model that simulates a magma chamber embedded in a more complicated distribution of materials, as indicated by seismic imaging, indicates a significantly deeper magma chamber having a depth of 3900 meters below the volcano?s surface. This result suggests that ignoring the seismic imaging information will strongly influence depth estimates of the volcano?s magmatic system. These results were found to be insensitive to the uncertainties in the seismic imaging. This implies that seismic imaging information, even if poorly focused, is essential to estimating the characteristics of a magma system, based on surface deformation data. These results are important for Okmok, as well as other volcanoes world-wide, because an accurate understanding of a magmatic system is essential for volcano eruption hazard assessments. The past few decades produced an explosion of data streams for active volcanoes, thanks to recent advances in space-borne instrumentation and computational capabilities. The project supported and served as the basis for Dr. Theodore Donovan?s Ph.D. research, which addressed the critical need for methods capable of integrating multiple types of information to advance our understanding of active volcanic systems. PI Masterlark and Dr. Donovan devised and executed sophisticated numerical models using the High Performance Computing hardware acquired by this project as a means achieve the project objectives. While the methods were specifically designed for Okmok Volcano, they are readily transportable for use to study other volcanoes having multiple types of information. Both PI Masterlark and Dr. Donovan presented preliminary results at multiple conferences during the project period in an effort to (1) inform the scientific community of their progress, (2) obtain insightful feedback from other researchers, and (3) ensure the free exchange of ideas regarding the project.
